## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I'm still learning about VerusIDs, and I had a question. How do VerusIDs prevent theft by allowing users to spend funds while their identity is locked?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, it's the opposite. VerusIDs do not allow users to spend funds while their identity is locked. In fact, staking-capable time locking and theft prevention (Verus Vault) enables identities to be locked, preventing any funds under their control from being spent while locked. This feature is designed to prevent theft by giving users a way to lock their identities and prevent unauthorized spending. Does that make sense?

**User:**
That's good to know. I was also wondering, are VerusIDs limited to the Verus network?

**AI Assistant:**
No, VerusIDs are not limited to the Verus network. The VerusID protocol is a protocol that can be implemented on non-Verus systems as well. This means that VerusIDs can be used on other systems beyond the Verus network. So, you can use your VerusID on other platforms that support the VerusID protocol.

**User:**
That's really cool. One more thing I wanted to ask: do users need to be programmers to create their own tokens or blockchains on the Verus network?

**AI Assistant:**
No, users do not need to be programmers to create their own tokens or blockchains on the Verus network. The Verus network allows any user with an ID to create their own token currency or even a full-fledged blockchain without requiring programming knowledge. The process is designed to be user-friendly, so you can focus on creating your own token or blockchain without needing to write code.
How do VerusIDs prevent theft by allowing users to spend funds while their identity is locked?

VerusIDs do not allow users to spend funds while their identity is locked. In fact, staking-capable time locking and theft prevention (Verus Vault) enables identities to be locked, preventing any funds under their control from being spent while locked. This feature is designed to prevent theft by giving users a way to lock their identities and prevent unauthorized spending.

f friendly name strong identities and funds addresses that are simultaneously fully self-sovereign, revocable, and recoverable.
## Staking-capable time locking and theft prevention (Verus Vault)
- Enables identities to be locked, preventing any funds under their control from being spent while locked, but still allowing seamless staking of funds. When locked, a user specifies an unlock delay, typically long enough to notice when someone who might have compromised a user’s keys would have to unlock the ID before spending. The only way to circumvent the unlock delay is to revoke and recover an ID. Users may also choose to create and use fresh private keys when unlocking an ID as well. This enables virtually theft proof workflow and a solution to inheritance, trusts, vesting schedules, the 5$ wrench attack, and identity theft. IDs may be used as friendly name cryptocurrency addresses for all currencies on all Verus PBaaS blockchains in the Verus network. The VerusID protocol is a protocol, which can also be implemented on non-Verus systems.
## Multi-currency, user created, decentralized tokens and merge-mineable, interoperable blockchains without programming
 - Enables any user with an ID to create their own token currency or even full fledged, multi-currency, ID-issuing 50% POW/50% POS, 51% hash attack resistant blockchain that can send and receive from the Verus chain which launched it. All PBaaS chains run from the same daemon, and projects may choose to join the worldwide Verus community in improving the daemon. In doing so, they will start with a complete, multi-currency, ID-capable blockchain with DeFi capabilities that is merge-mineable and stakeable with other blockchains in the Verus network.
